reviewText: The Next Level: Transitions, Turns and Layers takes up beautifully where Basics and Beyond leaves off. Unlike with many videos, there's no doubt that this is a clear step up from beginner to intermediate (for want of better terms).You begin with a challenging warm up. I've seen so many warm ups on so many belly dance videos. I'll tell you straight off that this one is different. It's not that there are new movements, but there are complex moves that change after just two or three repetitions. You begin with some head rolls following a figure-8 trajectory. You go on to some shoulder rolls. And that's where easy ends. From then on you go straight to undulations, double undulations with level changes, hip twists with a layer of upper body undulations and more and more moves. Some may find this quick-changes warm up difficult, in which case watching it a few times first is recommended.Continuing in the style of the warm up, Jenna takes you through a series of hip moves using the flow rather than the repetition method. You will not find yourself doing the same move 20 or 30 times. Rather, you'll go from one move to the other like a long, long combination in this hip layering drill. The "drill" aspect will have to come from doing this whole sequence many times. The moves include mayas with twists, twists with reverse undulations, one-hip horizontal circles layered on a traveling step... ah, there're too many to list!The upper body layering drill has rib cage circles, shoulder pushes and shimmies in different patterns, shoulder shimmies layered on chest slides, torso rotations, squares, hip circles, and on folkloric steps. This is a short, short intense drill. There's no breakdown and explanation of moves here. Remember.. this is the next level. If you need breakdowns you'll need to go back to Basics and Beyond. Both these drills are also a lesson in transitions as you move smoothly and quickly from one move to the other.Explanations begin in the turns section as Jenna breaks down each turn. She explains each in detail with all associated body movements, footwork, arm work, weight change, etc. She goes through several turns before moving into the actual drills segment. This begins with showing you how to spot. And then, systematically, you begin working on the turns, first with the main elements and adding on more as you go along. Many of these are used in the choreographies later on the DVD. Beautiful, graceful turns.The only thing that comes as a bit of a shock is that this too is a super short section. It's over before you know it. Thankfully, the choreographies will use what is in the drills and you'll get practice, but I have to admit I'd have liked much, much longer drill and turns sections, specially since that's the name of the video. However, I'm not taking a point off because the sheer amount of content, so well explained, is more than one could have ever hoped for.Celebration of RhythmI have thoroughly enjoyed learning this choreography. I worked with Jenna as systematically as she has worked to teach the 9 combinaitons that make up this choreography, set to Celebration of Rhythm from Jehan's GoddessDance CD. It's a saidi-like piece with the second half being quite drum solo like.  Jenna first demonstrates the whole choreography. Not in costume. And then we go through each combination, one at a time, with two rounds of practice with music each. Each combination has only its own practice sessions, not the previous ones in a building block format. I'm fine with focusing on one combination at a time. The teaching is at a lovely pace. Not too fast at all, and not painfully slow. And it's completely detailed.Raks BedeyaIf you add the previous 9 combinaitons to the 27 in the second choreography, you have a staggering 36 combinations on one DVD. And remember that's not the only thing on the video. When I compare this with a lot of other videos, specially some from IAMED, I'm amazed at the amount of content one gets for less than half the money. You can't get more generous with combinations, really. Two whole performable incredibly-taught choreographies.I haven't learnt this second choreo yet but plan on getting to it pretty soon. After Jillina's Egyptian Pop. It's a long, long tough one. Lots of turns, nuances, detail. It's a very pleasant choreography and one from which you'd be able to take away so much. All the transitions and turns are packed into this choreography. Get through it and it would affect the rest of your dancing, for certain.Raks Bedeya is from Wash Ya Wash 2 and is a lovely piece with lots of variation built into it. Changes of pace and all. This choreography moves a fraction faster and does have chunks practiced together rather than only one combo at a time, going all the way through 27.There's a cooldown of gentle stretches.Jenna performs both choreographies in costume. She looks cute and if you work witht his video, I'd really recommend looking at the full choreography on each practice session. You'll take in the nuances that kick in only during a stage performance.What would I give it on a 5-point scale? 9.
summary: Learn two whole choreographies and improve your skills with drills

reviewText: i just got this and so far played it 3 times. but after seeing the trailer here i decided to get it. reviewText: Wow, this is a great value for the money.  The beginning sections are like dance class drills to me, with a hip section, a chest section, and a turn section.  The hip and chest are just like a class, where she does it, you follow along, and move from one thing to another pretty quickly.  The turn section has more instruction, demonstrating the turns, then a second session is more of a class-like drill.  These sections alone are worth the price of the DVD.But then you get two choreographies, both broken down into combination sections.  The intermediate choreo has 9 combination sections, and the longer advanced choreo has nearly 30.  Even if you don't want to do the complete dance, there's a tremendous amount of material there to learn, practice, and use in your own ways.  This is like going to a workshop.My classes aren't a lot less than this DVD, and it would take a lot of classes to cover this much ground.  Very, very worth it.  Taught well, and very useful.  I don't recommend many bellydance DVDs but I recommend this one for intermediate dancers.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Just got this DVD the other day and must say that if you like Jenna's other DVD's this one is styled in much the same way.  My experience is beginner/intermediate.  I own Amira's beginning, Sensuous Blanca, Jenna's other two DVD's, the shimmies DVD, bellydance for fitness and well you get the drift.  So anyhow heres my breakdown on the 1-5 scale.  One is blah and 5 awesome.DVD Length-5thoroughness of instruction at intermediate level-5Visuals, nothing distracting, good view of legs-5Menu options-5Costumes-2 (this is so subjective, but wasn't thrilled especially with the red dress that covers a good deal of her bellyInstructor likablility-5Bang for buck-5 worth every penny and then some; nothing comparable in the intermediate rangeRecommend-5 this is my top pick for intermediates
summary: Great bang for your buck for intermediates
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just spent the afternoon 95min doing the drills and combinations of this DVD.  Now I have loads and loads of dance instructional DVDs but I must say that Michelle has kept this simple and effective.  She stands in front of mirror with her back to the camera so you get the benefit of both sides.Theres a million things to love about this DVD but I really want to highlight as a bellydancer and teacher of more than a decade if you take anything from this - let it remind you how to teach a choreography effectively.  Michelle does it as it should be:democombinations taught slowlypractise in slow modepractise at tempothis is done for several combinations.  Then she reveiews each combination at tempo again - repeating the combination at least 5 times before moving onto the next one.  Then its time to piece it all together for the routine but first this is done with the names of the combinations and grouped in around 4 parts.  Then its go for gold piece it all together.She is fantastic at her descriptions. Her combinations I found as a good mix that i guess i often forget to piece them together like that.  Im not sure if it was my space but i was seriously dripping at the end and of the several combinations I struggled with two that i need to go back and practise practise practise.Highly recommended.  I feel if anyone as an advance is bored by this you are not appreciating how she has structured everything.Thanks Michelle - really enjoyed my one-on-one all the way here in East Africa!
summary: Just what an advance bellydance teacher needs

reviewText: While I don't believe this is necessary for every belly dancers collection, it offers new perspective on how to layer moves.  Some of the moves look alluring, while others are on the awkward side. This DVD can be very frustrating and hard in the beginning if you don't have the patience. Jenna has plenty to offer someone looking for more complex moves. I recommend taking what you want out of it, leave the rest.

reviewText: Well produced, easy to follow...there's a wealth of information here that can keep a dancer occupied for awhile! I love the break down of the turns.  I FINALLY figured out the barrel turn after watching the DVD! It was like a lightbulb went off:) I also find it very helpful to have the camera behind Jenna while she faces the mirror, especially during the break down of the choreos. Makes it a lot easier to learn them.This DVD is also a useful tool for teachers looking for new ideas to bring to their intermediate/advanced classes.  Jenna uses clear explanations and great tips for all the movements taught, so a teacher is able to utilize some of these ideas to incorporate in their classes.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Belly Dance the next level with JennaAre you ready for new challenges? This enriching instructional  program;  one hour and 45 minutes, is perfect for those who want to go beyond basics after acquiring a firm foundation and basic knowledge in belly dance, ready to move to ahead to meet new challenges. This is a great step up to follow Jenna's Basics and Beyond instructional program. See how the basics of belly dance are taken into more complex moves to beautifully layer and enhance moves, transitions, turns, hip work.Three practice sessions specific for shoulders, hips and turnsThe warm-up session: thorough and enjoyable, set to pleasant music and involves every muscle; nothing is left out.  Jenna carefully guides a thorough  warm up, using undulations, hip arcs, circles, upper and lower body movements the various figure 8s. .Jenna is reflected from a mirror in a studio setting therefore you can see all angles.Hip work layering- in this section, Jenna leaves no stone unturned. Learn to co-ordinate hip and arm movement, using mayas with level change, adding twists to the hips while undulating, pelvic circles done in angles and center, scissor steps on toe layered with a circle, beautiful hip lifts layered with accents in and out, alternate with hips down, then add accents, slide the hips, then get ready for hip drops, shimmies, so much more. If you were ever at a loss at hip work, this will open your vocabulary.Upper body layering: full torso rotations, variations of shoulder shimmies while layering on chest circles and more shoulder shimmies, layered with traveling steps.Turns:  a necessary section for all dancers. Almost swan-like and graceful, these turns are all beautifully illustrated to music as Jenna describes and guides you through each step and arm placement. Here Jenna takes you into her concept of turns; how a simple 3 step turn can become a barrel turn; try a two step turn with accent or embellishment, a compass turn or a hip circle with reverse turn, a beautiful compass turn on a spin, a lovely character turn, embellished with oriental arms, a slick cross-over turn, a hip twist turn. Also included is a great practice session for all the turns in the section.Cool-down-Gentle yoga like asanas  with soothing music in the background as Jenna instructs each move carefully while demonstrating proper body alignment and placement.Jenna puts all her moves together for two great performances in full costume to 2 intermediate and advanced choreographies with step by step demonstration.This program is packed with instruction. I have learned much from Jenna's programs; her instruction is thorough,  detailed and precise in technique, guiding from the basic fundamentals of belly dance in a friendly approach. Jenna appears to be a wholesome teacher and if you cannot be present in her class, this dvd is the next best choice. I am grateful for such!
summary: Are you ready for a challenge?

reviewText: You have to love that Sarah Jessica Parker voice and the humbleness that is Jenna.  I am a dance instructor and I have watched many instructional dvds.  I can honestly say that Jenna gives the best explanations I've heard to date.  Her material is fun and she always provides a strong foundation.  I also love how she doesn't need to make 30 different dvds to get to the point; though I'd love to see another one soon!
